{{Relevant guide|Java Edition guides/Mounts of Mayhem}}
'''1.21.11''', the release of '''[[Mounts of Mayhem]]''', is a [[game drop]] for {{JE}} released on December 9, 2025,<ref>{{Mcnet|minecraft-java-edition-1-21-11|Minecraft Java Edition 1.21.11|December 9, 2025}}</ref><ref name="mcnet-image">{{mcnet|mounts-of-mayhem-official-release-date|Mounts of Mayhem official release date|2025-11-26T16:00:00Z|Sophie Austin}}</ref> which adds the [[nautilus]], [[zombie nautilus]], [[nautilus armor]], [[spear]]s, [[netherite horse armor]], [[camel husk]]s, [[parched]], and [[zombie horsemen]].

A separate [[unobfuscated version]] of 1.21.11 was released, titled '''1.21.11 Unobfuscated''' (or '''1.21.11_unobfuscated''' when in the launcher). This is an experimental version released in preparation for obfuscation being removed from ''Java Edition'' clients and servers.<ref>{{Mcnet|removing-obfuscation-in-java-edition|Removing obfuscation in Java Edition|October 29, 2025}}</ref>

1.21.11 is the final version of ''Java Edition'' to be obfuscated,<ref>{{Mcnet|minecraft-26-1-snapshot-1|Minecraft 26.1 Snapshot 1|December 16, 2025}}</ref> the final version released in 2025, the final version to require Java 21, and the final version to use the [[Version formats#Release|old 1.''x''.''y'' version format]].

=== Items ===
{{Animate|Copper Nautilus Armor (item).png;Iron Nautilus Armor (item).png;Golden Nautilus Armor (item).png;Diamond Nautilus Armor (item).png;Netherite Nautilus Armor (item).png|32px|class=pixel-image}} '''[[Nautilus armor]]'''
* Equippable on [[nautilus]]es and [[zombie nautilus]]es.
* Has [[Copper Nautilus Armor|copper]], [[Iron Nautilus Armor|iron]], [[Golden Nautilus Armor|gold]], [[Diamond Nautilus Armor|diamond]], and [[Netherite Nautilus Armor|netherite]] variants.
** Copper, iron, golden, and diamond nautilus armor now have a chance to be found in the [[chest]]s for the following [[structure]]s:
*** [[Buried treasure]]
*** [[Ocean ruins]]
*** [[Shipwreck]]
** Copper, iron and golden nautilus armor can be [[smelt]]ed into the respective [[nugget]]s.

'''[[File:Netherite Horse Armor (item).png|32px|class=pixel-image]] [[Netherite horse armor]]'''
* Can be obtained by upgrading [[diamond horse armor]] with a [[smithing table]] using [[netherite upgrade]] template.

{{Animate|s=Item|Nautilus Spawn Egg;Zombie Nautilus Spawn Egg;Parched Spawn Egg;Camel Husk Spawn Egg|32|class=pixel-image}} '''[[Spawn egg]]s'''
* Added nautilus, zombie nautilus, parched, and camel husk spawn eggs.

{{Animate|Wooden Spear.png;Stone Spear.png;Copper Spear.png;Iron Spear.png;Golden Spear.png;Diamond Spear.png;Netherite Spear.png|32px|class=pixel-image}} '''[[Spear]]'''
* New weapon that can be crafted in [[Wooden Spear|wood]], [[Stone Spear|stone]], [[Copper Spear|copper]], [[Iron Spear|iron]], [[Golden Spear|gold]], [[Diamond Spear|diamond]] and [[Netherite Spear|netherite]] versions.
** Each material has different stats for timing, influencing how fast they are to use.
** Copper, iron and golden spears can be smelted into the respective [[nugget]]s.
** Wooden spears can be used as a fuel in a [[furnace]].
* Cannot be used to mine blocks, as opposed to other weapons.
* Can be enchanted with the exclusive enchantment [[Lunge]], in addition to the available enchantments for [[sword]]s (except [[Sweeping Edge]]).
* Has a minimum reach for damage, being too close to a target will yield no damage.
** Has extended maximum reach compared to other tools and weapons.
* [[Zombie]]s, [[husk]]s, [[zombified piglin]]s and [[piglin]]s can spawn holding a spear.
** Golden spears are a [[piglin]]-preferred weapon.
* Has two attacks: jab and charge.
** Jab
*** Used by quick-pressing the {{control|attack|text=primary action button}}.
*** Is a low-damage attack with knockback.
*** Has a cooldown between attacks.
*** Wooden spears have the fastest cooldown, while netherite has the slowest.
*** Can hit multiple enemies.
** Charge
*** Used by holding the {{control|use|text=secondary action button}}.
*** Damage is based on spear material, the playerâ€™s view angle, and the velocity of both the player and the target.
*** While holding down the button, the attack goes through three stages before returning to idle:
**** Engaged: The spear can deal damage, knockback, and dismount mounted enemies if the speed is above the required thresholds.
**** Tired: Indicated by the spear rotating to a vertical position and shaking. The Spear can deal damage and knockback (but not dismount) if the speed is above the required thresholds.
**** Disengaged: Indicated by the spear being lowered, pointing downwards. The Spear gives damage but not knockback or dismount if the speed is above the required threshold.
*** The spear's range when used by mobs is half of that when used by players, but they can deal damage, dismount and knockback at lower speeds than the players.
*** Spears provide visual feedback when they hit a target in the charge attack.

=== Mobs ===
[[File:Camel_Husk_JE1.png|32px]] '''[[Camel husk]]'''
* New [[undead]] variant of the [[camel]].
* Spawns at a light level of 0 in [[desert]]s.
** Spawns with two riders: A [[husk]] wielding a [[spear]] in the front and a [[parched]] in the back.
** Does not spawn in [[caves]], following the husk's spawning rules.
* Does not burn in [[sunlight]].
* Has {{hp|32}} [[health]].
* Is hostile if the rider is a hostile mob (similar to the [[zombie horse]]). Is passive without a rider.
* Despawns like other hostile mobs, but becomes persistent while [[ridden]] by a player.
* Favorite food is [[rabbit foot]], but it cannot be [[bred]].
* Drops 2-3 [[rotten flesh]] when killed, with an extra 0-1 for each level of [[Looting]].
** Any husk riding it now has a chance of dropping a [[rabbit foot]] on death.
* As a mount, it works similar to a normal [[camel]].

[[File:Nautilus.png|32px]] '''[[Nautilus]]'''
* A new neutral [[aquatic]] mob.
* Spawns in all [[ocean]] biomes.
* Has {{hp|15}} health.
* Attacks using a dash attack, if provoked.
** Plays a dash sound when it performs its dash attack.
* Occasionally attacks [[pufferfish]] within range using the dash attack.
* Takes suffocation damage on land.
* Grants the [[Breath of the Nautilus]] effect to mounted players.
* Can be [[bred]] and [[tamed]] using a [[pufferfish (item)|pufferfish]] or a [[bucket of pufferfish]].
* A tamed nautilus can be equipped with a [[saddle]], then the player can [[ride]] it.
** While riding it, the player can use its dash attack (similar to [[camel]]s) by pressing the {{control|jump}} button.
** Has an inventory UI.
* Once tamed, has a roaming restriction around its home position of 16 blocks with a saddle, and 32 blocks without.
* Has a 5% ({{frac|1|20}}) chance of dropping a [[nautilus shell]] upon death, on a player kill, affected by [[Looting]].

[[File:Parched JE1 BE1.png|32px]] '''[[Parched]]'''
* New variant of the [[skeleton]].
* Spawns at a light level of 0 in deserts replacing some of the regular skeletons.
** Does not spawn in caves, following the [[husk]]'s spawning rules.
* Does not burn in sunlight.
* Has {{hp|16}} health.
* Shoots [[arrows of Weakness]], and has a chance to drop them as well.
* Has a slower rate of fire compared to a normal skeleton, similar to the [[bogged]].
* Is immune to the [[Weakness]] effect.

[[File:Zombie Nautilus.png|32px]] '''[[Zombie nautilus]]''' 
* A new underwater mob that spawns with a Drowned rider wielding a [[trident]].
* [[File:Coral Zombie Nautilus JE1.png|32px]] Has a coral variant, which appears when spawned in a [[warm ocean]] type biome.
* Hostile only if ridden by a hostile mob.
* Behaves similar to the nautilus except that it cannot be bred.
* Burns in sunlight, like other [[undead]] mobs.
** Nautilus armor protects it from sunlight damage.
* Does not take suffocation damage on land, as opposed to regular nautilus.
* Drops 0-3 [[rotten flesh]] when killed, on a player kill, affected by [[Looting]].

=== Command format ===
'''{{cmd|stopwatch}}'''
* New command that allows the creation of a stopwatch that keeps track of real time.
* Stopwatches do not depend on game ticks.
* They only run when the server/world is running, even when paused.
* Syntax:
** {{cmd|stopwatch create <id>}} &ndash; creates a stopwatch with the given namespaced ID.
** {{cmd|stopwatch query <id>}} &ndash; returns the queried value and takes in a new {{cd|scale}} argument.
*** The returned value will be scaled by that argument and truncated.
*** The scale is optional and will default to {{cd|1}} if omitted.
*** Example: {{cmd|stopwatch query foo:bar 20}} to get the elapsed time in ticks.
** {{cmd|stopwatch restart <id>}} &ndash; restarts the given stopwatch.
** {{cmd|stopwatch remove <id>}} &ndash; removes the given stopwatch.

'''[[Effect]]s'''

'''[[Enchantments]]'''
* [[Lunge]]
** A new enchantment that is unique to the [[spear]].
** Only works with the jab attack.
** When doing a jab attack with Lunge, it propels the player horizontally in the view direction.
** The view angle needs to be perfectly leveled horizontally to achieve maximum lunge distance.
** Costs saturation/hunger to use, similar to sprinting or jumping.
*** Level I consumes {{hunger|1}}, level II consumes {{hunger|2}}, and level III consumes {{hunger|3}}.
*** Lunge can only be used if the player has at least {{hunger|6}} hunger points in their hunger bar.
** There's also a durability cost of 1 for using [[Lunge]] across all Enchantment levels.

=== General ===
'''[[Environment attribute]]s'''
{{collapse|
content=
* Provides a data-driven way to control a variety of visual and gameplay systems.
* Each Environment Attribute controls a specific visual or gameplay effect: 
** For example, {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_color}} controls the color of the sky, and {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/water_evaporates}} controls whether water can be placed at a given location.

* Sources
** Environment Attribute values can be provided by the following Environment Attribute sources (in order of low to high priority):
*** Dimensions
*** Biomes
** The "effective" value of the Environment Attribute (i.e. what will actually show up in game) will be some combination of the values provided by each source according to their priority.
*** For example, in the following scenario:
**** The overworld dimension provides <code>sky_color = #00ff00</code> (green)
**** The plains biome provides <code>sky_color = #ff0000</code> (red)
*** When the player is in the plains biome, they will see the red {{cd|sky_color}}, while anywhere else in the overworld they will see green.
** When an Environment Attribute source provides an Environment Attribute, it can:
*** Override the value, such as the plains biome overriding the overworld's {{cd|sky_color}} in the above scenario.
*** Apply a modifier to a previous value.

* Modifiers
** An environment attribute source may simply override the value of a particular attribute. 
*** However, it is sometimes also desirable to rather apply a modifier to a value provided by a source with lower priority.
*** For example, in the following scenario:
**** The overworld dimension provides <code>water_fog_radius = 96.0</code>
**** The plains biome modifies {{cd|water_fog_radius}} with a multiply modifier of {{cd|0.85}}
*** When in the plains biome, the {{cd|water_fog_radius}} will be resolved to <math>96.0*0.85 = 81.6</math>, while in any other Overworld biome, it will resolve to {{cd|96.0}}.
** The kinds of modifiers available depends on the type of Environment Attribute. 
*** The most basic modifier, supported by every Environment Attribute, is the override modifier. 
*** This behaves purely as an override of the preceding value. 
**** If not specified by an Environment Attribute source, the modifier will always be assumed to be override.

* Interpolation
** Interpolation describes the combination of values within a source. 
** Is performed on values from a source after modifiers have been applied.
** Only some Environment Attributes support interpolation. This allows for the smooth transition between two or more values, such as when moving between two biomes.
** Biomes
*** {{cd|sky_color}} is one attribute that will transition smoothly based on position.
*** For example, in the following scenario:
**** The plains biome provides <code>sky_color = #ff0000</code> (red)
**** The desert biome provides <code>sky_color = #ffff00</code> (yellow)
*** In the above scenario, as a player moves from a plains to a desert biome, the sky color will gradually shift from red to yellow. 
*** Other attributes, such as {{cd|water_evaporates}}, represent discrete values and will not be smoothly transitioned &ndash; only the biome exactly at a subject position will be considered.
*** Smooth transitions between biomes are based on the biomes within an 8 block radius of the camera. Biomes that occupy a larger portion of that radius and are closer to the camera will have a stronger influence on the final interpolated value.

* Environment Attribute Map
** Dimension Type and Biome definitions contain a new attributes field, enabling them to define Environment Attributes.
** This map generally takes the form of an object mapping between Environment Attribute IDs and their corresponding values, for example:
<code>"attributes": {
"minecraft:visual/fog_color": "#ffaa00",
"minecraft:gameplay/water_evaporates": true
}</code>
* Values defined as above will always be assumed to use the override modifier.
** The value object can however be expanded in order to express different modifiers, in the format of an object with the following fields:
*** {{cd|modifier}}: optional string modifier ID, dependent on the Attribute Type.
**** Default: {{cd|override}}
*** {{cd|argument}}: the modifier argument (format dependent on the chosen modifier).
**** How the argument is used also depends on the type of modifier.
*** For example, the following definition describes multiplying {{cd|water_fog_radius}} by 85%:
<code>"attributes": {
"minecraft:visual/water_fog_radius": {
"modifier": "multiply",
"argument": 0.85
}
}</code>

* Common Data Types
** The following data types are reused in various parts of the Environment Attributes system.
** RGB Color
*** Format can be one of the following:
**** A hex color RGB string, in the form {{cd|#rrggbb}}
**** A float array with 3 components, between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, in the form {{cd|[r, g, b]}}
**** An integer in packed RGB form.
** ARGB Color
*** Format can be one of the following:
**** A hex color ARGB string, in the form {{cd|#aarrggbb}}
**** A float array with 4 components, between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, in the form {{cd|[a, r, g, b]}}
**** An integer in packed ARGB form.
** Particle Options
*** A full definition of a particle, including any type-specific properties (as in the /particle command).
**** For example:
<code>{
"type": "minecraft:block_crumble",
"block_state": {
"Name": "minecraft:dirt"
}
}</code>

* Common Modifiers
* Every Environment Attribute has a specific value type, which describes how values must be defined as well as what modifiers are available and how they are interpolated. 
** Some are very specific, while others are reused across many attributes.
** Modifiers on Boolean Values
*** Argument format: boolean
**** {{cd|override}}
**** {{cd|and}}
**** {{cd|nand}}
**** {{cd|or}}
**** {{cd|nor}}
**** {{cd|xor}}
**** {{cd|xnor}}
** Modifiers on Float Values
*** Argument format: float
**** {{cd|override}}
**** {{cd|add}}
**** {{cd|subtract}}
**** {{cd|multiply}}
**** {{cd|minimum}}
**** {{cd|maximum}}
** Modifiers on Color Values
*** Argument format: RGB color (except {{cd|alpha_blend}})
**** {{cd|override}}
**** {{cd|add}} &ndash; component-wise additive color blending
**** {{cd|subtract}} &ndash; component-wise subtractive color blending..
**** {{cd|multiply}} &ndash; component-wise multiplicative color blending.
**** {{cd|alpha_blend}} &ndash; traditional alpha blending that might be seen in image editing software.
***** Argument format: ARGB Color
***** When the argument alpha is {{cd|1}}, it will behave as an override with no blending.
** Modifiers on ARGB Color Values
*** {{cd|override}}
**** Argument format: ARGB Color
*** {{cd|add}} &ndash; component-wise additive color blending.
**** Argument format: RGB Color
*** {{cd|subtract}} &ndash; component-wise subtractive color blending.
**** Argument format: RGB Color
*** {{cd|multiply}} &ndash; component-wise multiplicative color blending.
**** Argument format: RGB or ARGB Color
**** If specified, the alpha component is multiplied independently just like the other color channels.
*** {{cd|alpha_blend}} &ndash; traditional alpha blending that might be seen in image editing software.
**** Argument format: ARGB Color
**** When the argument alpha is {{cd|1}}, it will behave as an override with no blending.

* New Environment Attributes
** {{cd|minecraft:visual/fog_color}}
*** The color of fog (when the camera is not submerged in another substance).
**** Value type: RGB color
**** Default value: {{cd|#000000}}
**** Modifiers: Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.fog_color}} field.
*** Note: the final value is also affected by the time of day, weather, and potion effects.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/fog_start_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which fog starts to have an effect (when the camera is not submerged in another substance). If negative, the fog will start out with density as if it had started that many blocks behind the camera. Note: the final value is also modified by weather.
**** Value type: float
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/fog_end_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which fog reaches its maximum density (when the camera is not submerged in another substance).
**** Value type: non-negative float
**** Default value: {{cd|1024.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Note: the final value is also modified by weather.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/water_fog_color}}
*** The color of fog when submerged in water. 
**** Value type: RGB color
**** Default value: {{cd|#050533}}
**** Modifiers: Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.water_fog_color}} field.
*** Note: the final value is also affected by the time of day, weather, and potion effects.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/water_fog_start_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which underwater fog starts to have an effect. If negative, the fog will start out with density as if it had started that many blocks behind the camera.
**** Value type: float
**** Default value: {{cd|-8.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/water_fog_end_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which underwater fog reaches its maximum density.
**** Value type: non-negative float
**** Default value: {{cd|96.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces {{cd|#has_closer_water_fog}} Biome Tag.
*** Note: the final value is also modified by how long the player has been underwater.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_fog_end_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which the fog that affects the sky reaches its maximum density (when the camera is not submerged in another substance).
**** Value type: non-negative float
**** Default value: {{cd|512.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Note: this value is restricted by the Render Distance option.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/cloud_fog_end_distance}}
*** The distance in blocks from the camera at which the fog that affects clouds reaches its maximum density (when the camera is not submerged in another substance).
**** Value type: non-negative float
**** Default value: {{cd|2048.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Note: this value is restricted by the Cloud Distance option.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_color}}
*** The color of the sky. This color is only visible for the overworld sky.
**** Value type: RGB color
**** Default value: {{cd|#000000}}
**** Modifiers: Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.sky_color}} field.
*** Note: the final value is also affected by the time of day and weather.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_light_color}}
*** The visual color of sky light. For blocks with a sky light level of 0 (or {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_light_factor}} is {{cd|0}}), this will have no effect. This is the value passed to the <samp>lightmap.fsh</samp> shader as {{cd|SkyLightColor}}.
**** Value type: RGB Color
**** Default value: <code>{{color|#ffffff}}</code>
**** Modifiers: RGB Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_light_factor}}
*** The visual brightness of sky light. {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_light_color}} is multiplied by this value. This is the value passed to the <samp>lightmap.fsh</samp> shader as {{cd|SkyFactor}}.
*** The corresponding gameplay effect is controlled entirely by {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/sky_light_level}}.
**** Value type: float
**** Default value: {{cd|1.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/cloud_color}}
*** The color of the clouds. If fully transparent, clouds are entirely disabled and [[happy ghast]]s will not regenerate health faster when at cloud height.
**** Value type: ARGB color
**** Default value: {{cd|#00000000}}
**** Modifiers: ARGB Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position for rendering, or at the position of a [[happy ghast]] for regeneration.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/cloud_height}}
*** The height at which all clouds appear.
**** Value type: float
**** Default value: {{cd|192.33}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position for rendering, or at the position of a [[happy ghast]] for regeneration.
**** Replaces Dimension Type {{cd|cloud_height}} field.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/default_dripstone_particle}}
*** The default particle to be dripped from [[dripstone block]]s when no fluid is placed above.
**** Value type: Particle Options
**** Default value: {{cd|{type:"minecraft:dripping_dripstone_water"}}}
**** Modifiers: {{cd|override}}
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the position of the [[dripstone block]].
**** Replaces Dimension Type {{cd|ultrawarm}} field.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/ambient_particles}}
*** Controls ambient particles that randomly spawn around the camera.
**** Value type: list of objects with fields
***** {{cd|particle}}: Particle Options to spawn.
***** {{cd|probability}}: float between 0 and 1, the probability to spawn the particle in an empty space when randomly ticked.
**** Default value: {{cd|[]}}
**** Modifiers: {{cd|override}}
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.particle}} field.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sunrise_sunset_color}}
*** Controls the color and intensity of the sunrise and sunset effect. If fully transparent, no sunrise or sunset will be rendered. Only visible with the overworld skybox type.
**** Value type: ARGB Color
**** Default value: <code>{{color|#00000000}}</code>
**** Modifiers: ARGB Color Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sun_angle}}
*** The angle in degrees of the sun, clockwise from east to west, with {{cd|0}} being directly up.
**** Value type: float, angle in degrees
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/moon_angle}}
*** The angle in degrees of the moon, clockwise from east to west, with {{cd|0}} being directly up.
**** Value type: float, angle in degrees
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/moon_phase}}
*** The phase of the moon.
**** Value type: string id, one of:
***** {{cd|full_moon}}
***** {{cd|waning_gibbous}}
***** {{cd|third_quarter}}
***** {{cd|waning_crescent}}
***** {{cd|new_moon}}
***** {{cd|waxing_crescent}}
***** {{cd|first_quarter}}
***** {{cd|waxing_gibbous}}
**** Default value: "{{cd|full_moon}}"
**** Modifiers: override
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/star_angle}}
*** The angle in degrees of the stars, clockwise from east to west, with {{cd|0}} being directly up.
**** Value type: float, angle in degrees
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:visual/star_brightness}}
*** The brightness of the stars in the sky, where {{cd|0.5}} is the normal brightness during the night and {{cd|0}} is fully hidden.
**** Value type: float between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: yes
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
*** Only visible with the overworld skybox type.

** {{cd|minecraft:audio/background_music}}
*** Controls how and which background music is played.
**** Value type: object with fields
***** {{cd|default}}: optional object with fields:
****** {{cd|sound}}: Sound Event to play.
****** {{cd|min_delay}}: int, minimum delay in ticks between tracks.
****** {{cd|max_delay}}: int, maximum delay in ticks between tracks.
****** {{cd|replace_current_music}}: optional boolean, whether this track can replace whatever is currently playing.
******* Default: false
****** If not defined and not overridden, no music will start playing while this attribute is active.
***** {{cd|underwater}}: optional object with fields in the same format as default &ndash; if present and the player is underwater, will override default.
***** {{cd|creative}}: optional object with fields in the same format as default &ndash; if present and the player is in Creative Mode, will override default.
**** Default value: <code>{}</code>
**** Modifiers: {{cd|override}}
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.music}} field.

** {{cd|minecraft:audio/music_volume}}
*** The volume at which music should play. Any music playing will fade over time to this value.
**** Value type: float between 0 and 1
**** Default value: {{cd|1.0}}
**** Modifiers: Float Modifiers
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.music_volume}} field.

** {{cd|minecraft:audio/ambient_sounds}}
*** Controls which ambient sounds are played around the camera, and when.
**** Value type: object with fields
***** {{cd|loop}}: optional Sound Event, sound to be continually looped.
***** {{cd|mood}}: object with fields, sounds that will be randomly played based on surrounding darkness.
****** {{cd|sound}}: Sound Event to play.
****** {{cd|tick_delay}}: int, the number of ticks between mood sounds, assuming a light level of 0.
****** {{cd|block_search_extent}}: int, the radius in which light levels are sampled.
****** {{cd|offset}}: double, an additional distance offset to apply to sounds produced.
***** {{cd|additions}}: list of objects with fields, sounds that will be randomly played.
****** {{cd|sound}}: Sound Event to play
****** {{cd|tick_chance}}: float between 0 and 1, probability within a tick to play a given sound.
**** Default value: <code>{}</code>
**** Modifiers: {{cd|override}}
**** Interpolated: no
**** Resolved at the camera's position.
**** Replaces Biome {{cd|effects.ambient_sound}}, {{cd|effects.mood_sound}}, and {{cd|effects.additions_sound}} fields.

** {{cd|minecraft:audio/firefly_bush_sounds}}
*** If {{cd|true}} and not below an opaque block, [[firefly bushes]] will produce idle sounds.
**** Value type: boolean
**** Default value: {{cd|false}}
**** Modifiers: Boolean Modifiers
**** Interpolated: no

***** {{cd|explodes}} &ndash; optional boolean, if true the bed will explode when interacted with.

'''[[Game rule]]s'''
* Added {{cd|minecraft:fire_spread_radius_around_player}}
** Controls the maximum distance in blocks that fire can spread around a player.
*** This replaces the previous {{cd|doFireTick}} and {{cd|allowFireTicksAwayFromPlayer}} game rules, which have now been removed.
*** Setting it to {{cd|0}} will disable fire spreading.
*** Setting it to {{cd|-1}} will allow fire spreading without players around.
*** Limit: Minimum {{cd|-1}}

'''[[Data component format|Item components]]'''
* {{cd|minecraft:attack_range}}
** Enables a custom attack range when using the item.
** Overrides the normal entity interaction range for player.
** Regular melee attack range is computed for mobs based on the distance of the target hitbox to their hitbox. This component modifies that distance check by adjusting minimum and maximum padding for the attack hitbox.
** Mobs using {{cd|minecraft:kinetic_weapon}} will have their attack range applied in the same way it applies to players.
** Format: object with fields
*** {{cd|min_reach}}: float, the minimum distance in blocks from the attacker to the target to be considered valid.
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|64.0}}
*** {{cd|max_reach}}: float, the maximum distance in blocks from the attacker to the target to be considered valid.
**** Default value: {{cd|3.0}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|64.0}}
*** {{cd|min_creative_reach}}: float, the minimum distance in blocks from the Creative Mode attacker to the target to be considered valid.
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|64.0}}
*** {{cd|max_creative_reach}}: float, the maximum distance in blocks from the Creative Mode attacker to the target to be considered valid.
**** Default value: {{cd|5.0}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|64.0}}
*** {{cd|hitbox_margin}}: float, the margin applied to the target bounding box when checking for valid hitbox collision.
**** Default value: {{cd|0.3}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|1.0}}
*** {{cd|mob_factor}}: float, the multiplier applied to the {{cd|min_range}} and {{cd|max_range}} when checking for valid distance when item is used by a mob.
**** Default value: {{cd|1.0}}, valid from {{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|2.0}}

* {{cd|minecraft:damage_type}}
** Specifies the type of damage this item deals.
** Format: string, damage type identifier.
*** e.g. <code>damage_type='minecraft:spear'</code>

* {{cd|minecraft:kinetic_weapon}}
** Enables a charge-type attack when using the item (primarily for Spears), where, while being used, the damage is dealt along a ray every tick based on the relative speed of the entities.
** Format: object with fields.
*** {{cd|delay_ticks}}: integer, the time in ticks required before weapon is effective.
**** Default value: {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|dismount_conditions}}: Indicates the condition to apply dismount. Objects with fields:
**** {{cd|max_duration_ticks}}: integer, the ticks after which the condition is no longer checked. This starts after delay has elapsed.
**** {{cd|min_speed}}: float, the minimum speed of the attacker, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** {{cd|min_relative_speed}}: float, the minimum relative speed between the attacker and target, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|knockback_conditions}}: Indicates the condition to apply knockback. Objects with fields:
**** {{cd|max_duration_ticks}}: integer, the ticks after which the condition is no longer checked. This starts after delay has elapsed.
**** {{cd|min_speed}}: float, the minimum speed of the attacker, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** {{cd|min_relative_speed}}: float, the minimum relative speed between the attacker and target, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|damage_conditions}}: Indicates the condition to apply damage effects. Objects with fields:
**** {{cd|max_duration_ticks}}: integer, the ticks after which the condition is no longer checked. This starts after delay has elapsed.
**** {{cd|min_speed}}: float, the minimum speed of the attacker, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
**** {{cd|min_relative_speed}}: float, the minimum relative speed between the attacker and target, in blocks per second, along the direction that the attacker is looking.
***** Optional, default value: {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|forward_movement}}: float, the distance the item moves out of hand during animation.
**** Default value: {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|damage_multiplier}}: float, the multiplier for the final damage from the relative speed.
**** Default value: {{cd|1.0}}
*** {{cd|sound}}: Optional Sound Event to play when the weapon is engaged.
*** {{cd|hit_sound}}: Optional Sound Event to play when the weapon hits an entity.
*** {{cd|contact_cooldown_ticks}}: integer, the cooldown in ticks after hitting, and loosing contact with an entity before being able to hit it again.
**** Default value: {{cd|10}}
*** e.g. <code>kinetic_weapon={max_reach:5.0,forward_movement:1.0,delay:20,damage_conditions:{max_duration_ticks:60},knockback_conditions:{max_duration_ticks:40},dismount_conditions:{max_duration_ticks:20}}</code>
** The damage dealt is calculated as <math>floor(relative_speed * velocity_multiplier)</math> where {{cd|relative_speed}} is the difference of speed vectors of the attacker and the target as projected onto the axis of the attacker's view vector.
*** Any additional damage from enchantments or attribute modifiers is * after this calculation.

* {{cd|minecraft:minimum_attack_charge}}
** Sets the minimum attack charge on the attack indicator required to attack with this item.
** Format: float ({{cd|0.0}} to {{cd|1.0}}).
*** {{cd|0.0}}: no charge required.
*** {{cd|1.0}}: full charge required.

* {{cd|minecraft:piercing_weapon}}
** Enables a quick attack that damages multiple entities along a ray (primarily for Spears).
** Format: object with fields.
*** {{cd|deals_knockback}}: boolean, whether the attack deals knockback.
**** Default value: {{cd|true}}
*** {{cd|dismounts}}: boolean, whether the attack dismounts the target.
**** Default value: {{cd|false}}
*** {{cd|sound}}: Optional Sound Event to play when a player attacks with the weapon.
*** {{cd|hit_sound}}: Optional Sound Event to play when the weapon hits an entity.
*** e.g. <code>piercing_weapon={min_reach:0,max_reach:4,dismounts:true}</code>

* {{cd|minecraft:swing_animation}}
** Specifies the swing animation to play when attacking or interacting using this item.
** Format: object with fields.
*** {{cd|type}}: string, the animation identifier ({{cd|none}}, {{cd|whack}}, {{cd|stab}}).
**** Default value: {{cd|whack}}
*** {{cd|duration}}: integer, the duration in ticks.
**** Default value: {{cd|6}}
*** e.g. <code>swing_animation={type:'stab',duration:20}</code>

* {{cd|minecraft:use_effects}}
** Controls how the player behaves when using an item (right mouse click).
** Format: object with fields.
*** {{cd|can_sprint}}: boolean, whether the player can sprint while using this item.
**** Default value: {{cd|false}}
*** {{cd|speed_multiplier}}: float ({{cd|0}} to {{cd|1}}), the speed multiplier applied to the player while using this item.
**** Default value: {{cd|0.2}}
*** {{cd|interact_vibrations}}: boolean
**** Whether using this item emits {{cd|minecraft:item_interact_start}} and {{cd|minecraft:item_interact_finish}} game events.
**** Default value: {{cd|true}}
***e.g. <code>use_effects={can_sprint:true,speed_multiplier:1.0}</code>

'''[[Loot functions]]'''
* {{cd|minecraft:discard}}
** Replaces any item stack with empty one.
** No fields.

'''[[Options]]'''
* Added the anisotropic filtering graphics option.
** This new option improves the visual quality of blocks when viewed at a distance or at an angle.
** The default depends on the graphics preset, and the values are "off", "2x", "4x", and "8x".
** If the hardware does not support it, it will not be used.
** This significantly impacts video memory usage (especially combined with a high mipmap count).

* Added the chunk fade time option.
** Located in Video Settings.
** Controls the fade-in time of [[chunk]]s.

[[File:1.21.11-pre1 VV Java Tech changelog.png|300px|thumb|An announcement on Rotated Grid Super Sampling.]]
* Added texture filtering in video settings.
** Controls the method used to sample textures when they are viewed at an angle or from a distance.
** Available values are "None", "RGSS", and "Anisotropic".
** The default depends on the selected graphics preset as well as the computer's graphics card capabilities.{{note|AMD GPUs use "RGSS" on the "Fabulous!" preset instead of "Anisotropic" as using "Anisotropic" on AMD GPUs does not perform well.<ref>{{Cite Discord
|url=https://discord.com/channels/1138536747932864532/1424838127800942662/1440656198822133782
|channel=dev-updates
|server=Minecraft Feedback
|invite=https://discord.gg/minecraftfeedback
|user=timur6030
|date=November 18, 2025
|ss=1.21.11-pre1_VV_Java_Tech_changelog.png
}}</ref>}}
** "RGSS" (Rotated Grid Super Sampling) is a shader-based filtering method that improves texture clarity at a moderate performance cost.
*** This is available on all hardware.
** "Anisotropic" is a hardware-based filtering method that improves texture clarity even further.
*** The maximum anisotropy may be "2x", "4x", and "8x", controllable by a separate slider.
*** If the graphics card does not support it, anisotropic filtering will do nothing.
*** This significantly impacts [[w:Video random-access memory|VRAM]] usage (especially combined with a high mipmap count).

'''[[Slot sources]]'''
* Added slot sources to allow the location of any inventory slot to be specified within datapacks.
** Format: object with fields.
*** {{cd|type}}: the slot source type.
*** {{cd|<type-specific>}}: additional fields depending on the type.

* {{cd|minecraft:empty}} Type
** Empty selection containing no slots.

* {{cd|minecraft:group}} Type
** Merges several slot sources into one, with the resulting selection containing all slots from each slot source provided.
*** If a slot is included in more than one slot source, it will be repeated in the resulting slot source.
*** e.g. {{cd|[a, b] + [c, a]}} -> {{cd|[a, b, c, a]}}
** Format:
*** {{cd|terms}}: list of slot sources to join.
** Can alternatively be written inline as a list of slot sources.

* {{cd|minecraft:slot_range}} Type
** Selects slots within a slot range from the inventory of an entity or block entity.
** Mirrors the behavior of the {{cd|from}} argument of the {{cmd|item}} command.
** Format:
*** {{cd|source}}: an entity or block entity from which the slots will be sourced, from loot context.
**** Can be {{cd|block_entity}}, this, {{cd|attacking_entity}}, {{cd|last_damage_player}}, {{cd|direct_attacker}}, {{cd|target_entity}}, or {{cd|interacting_entity}}
*** {{cd|slots}}: a slot range in the format of {{cd|<slot_type>}} or {{cd|<slot_type>.<slot_number>}} (e.g. {{cd|armor.chest}} or {{cd|container.*}}).

* {{cd|minecraft:contents}} Type
** Selects all non-empty slots from the inventory component of one or more items.
*** If no item is stored inside that component, the resulting selection will be empty.
** The location of the item(s) whose inventory component to use is specified by another slot source.
*** If the slot source includes more than one item with that component, the resulting selections will be merged identically as with the {{cd|minecraft:group}} type.
*** e.g. {{cd|Bundle [a, b] + Shulker Box [c, d]}} -> {{cd|[a, b, c, d]}}
** Format:
*** {{cd|component}}: the inventory component to target.
**** Allowed values are {{cd|minecraft:bundle_contents}}, {{cd|minecraft:charged_projectiles}}, and {{cd|minecraft:container}}
*** {{cd|slot_source}}: a slot source containing slots with item(s) to target.

* {{cd|minecraft:filtered}} Type
** Applies a filter to the selected slots, excluding any non-matching slots from the resulting selection.
** Format:
*** {{cd|item_filter}}: an item predicate to match against the items in each slot.
*** {{cd|slot_source}}: the slot source to filter.

* {{cd|minecraft:limit_slots}} Type
** Limits the number of slots provided, with the resulting selection containing at most that number of slots.
*** Any slots bringing the number of slots above that limit will be excluded, in order of inclusion.
*** e.g. {{cd|[a, b, c, d]}} -> {{cd|[a, b, c]}} if the limit is set to {{cd|3}}
** Format:
*** {{cd|limit}}: integer, the maximum number of slots to include in the resulting selection.
*** {{cd|slot_source}}: the slot source to limit.
* Example slot source selecting every slot with more than 16 items from the hotbar and armor slots of an entity:
<syntaxhighlight lang="json">{
    "type": "minecraft:filtered",
    "item_filter": {
        "count": {
            "min": 16
        }
    },
    "slot_source": [
        {
            "type": "minecraft:slot_range",
            "source": "this",
            "slots": "hotbar.*"
        },
        {
            "type": "minecraft:slot_range",
            "source": "this",
            "slots": "armor.*"
        }
    ]
}</syntaxhighlight>

'''[[Timeline]]s'''
* Are a new experimental concept defined in data packs under the timeline registry (i.e. found under <samp>data/<''namespace''>/timeline/<''id''>.json</samp>).
* Specify game behavior based on the absolute day time (that which is set by {{cmd|time set}}). Timelines optionally can specify a period over which they will be repeated.
* Are able to modify game behavior or visuals by acting as an Environment Attribute source to apply Environment Attribute modifiers.
** Format: object with fields
*** {{cd|period_ticks}}: optional integer, defines the duration in ticks over which the timeline will repeat.
**** If not specified, the timeline will not repeat
*** {{cd|tracks}}: optional map between Environment Attribute IDs and a corresponding Environment Attribute Track object.
* Timelines by default have no effect unless they are included by a dimension.
* With the inclusion of Timelines, Environment Attribute sources are processed in the following order (from low to high priority):
** Dimensions
** Biomes
** Timelines
** Weather (not data-driven)
* Interpolation
** Timelines can define Attribute Tracks 
*** These specify how a modifier for a particular Environment Attribute changes over time by defining keyframes. 
*** Depending on the attribute, interpolation may be used between each keyframe. If interpolation is not used, the previous keyframe value will always be selected.
** For example, a Timeline with a period of 24000 might be set up as following:
*** At time = {{cd|0}}, the timeline provides {{cd|sky_color {{=}} #ff0000}} (red)
*** At time = {{cd|1000}}, the timeline provides {{cd|sky_color {{=}} #ff0000}} (red)
*** At time = {{cd|6000}}, the timeline provides {{cd|sky_color {{=}} #ff00ff}} (magenta)
** Between time = {{cd|0}} and time = {{cd|1000}}, the sky color will be red. Between {{cd|1000}} and {{cd|6000}}, it will shift from red to magenta. Then, from {{cd|6000}} all the way until the timeline repeats and reaches time = {{cd|0}} again, the color will slowly shift back to red.
** Unlike biomes, if a Timeline uses a modifier instead of an override, interpolation is applied to the modifier arguments rather than the final modified values.
* Attribute Tracks
** An Attribute Track specified within a Timeline takes the format of an object with the following fields:
*** {{cd|ease}} &ndash; optional Easing Type (see below), used to ease the interpolaton of the value between keyframes.
**** Default: linear
***** If the target attribute does not support interpolation, the easing mode will have no effect.
*** {{cd|keyframes}} &ndash; list of keyframe objects, must be ordered by the ticks field:
**** {{cd|ticks}} &ndash; integer between 0 and period_ticks (if specified), defines the tick (within the period) at which this keyframe's value will be active.
**** {{cd|value}} &ndash; the modifier argument (format dependent on the chosen modifier).
***** If no modifier is specified (or override is used), the type of this field is the same as the Environment Attribute itself.
***** How this value is used depends on the type of modifier.
****** Note: at most two keyframes can be placed on the same tick, creating an immediate transition.
*** {{cd|modifier}} &ndash; optional string modifier ID, dependent on the Attribute Type (see the Common Modifiers section below).
**** Default: override
** For example, the following Timeline has a period of {{cd|24000}}, and has an attribute track that modifies only {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/cat_waking_up_gift_chance}}. Because the easing is constant, between tick {{cd|362}} and {{cd|23667}} the value is {{cd|0.0}}, while between tick {{cd|23667}} and {{cd|362}} it is {{cd|0.7}}.
** Like other Environment Attribute sources, the specified value is used as the argument to the specified {{cd|modifier}}. This is then applied on top of sources with a lower priority. In this case the modifier is {{cd|maximum}}, so this timeline will only ever increase the value of {{cd|cat_waking_up_gift_chance}} to the value specified in the track.

<syntaxhighlight lang="JSON">
{
    "period_ticks": 24000,
    "tracks": {
        "minecraft:gameplay/cat_waking_up_gift_chance": {
            "ease": "constant",
            "modifier": "maximum",
            "keyframes": [
                { "ticks": 362,   "value": 0.0 },
                { "ticks": 23667, "value": 0.7 }
            ]
        }
    }
}
</syntaxhighlight>

* Easing Types
** Easing Types control the interpolation between two keyframes by applying a curve. The following built-in Easing Types are provided:
*** {{cd|constant}} &ndash; always selects the previous keyframe
*** {{cd|linear}}
*** {{cd|in_back}}
*** {{cd|in_bounce}}
*** {{cd|in_circ}}
*** {{cd|in_cubic}}
*** {{cd|in_elastic}}
*** {{cd|in_expo}}
*** {{cd|in_quad}}
*** {{cd|in_quart}}
*** {{cd|in_quint}}
*** {{cd|in_sine}}
*** {{cd|in_out_back}}
*** {{cd|in_out_bounce}}
*** {{cd|in_out_circ}}
*** {{cd|in_out_cubic}}
*** {{cd|in_out_elastic}}
*** {{cd|in_out_expo}}
*** {{cd|in_out_quad}}
*** {{cd|in_out_quart}}
*** {{cd|in_out_quint}}
*** {{cd|in_out_sine}}
*** {{cd|out_back}}
*** {{cd|out_bounce}}
*** {{cd|out_circ}}
*** {{cd|out_cubic}}
*** {{cd|out_elastic}}
*** {{cd|out_expo}}
*** {{cd|out_quad}}
*** {{cd|out_quart}}
*** {{cd|out_quint}}
*** {{cd|out_sine}}
** An Easing Type may also be specified with a Cubic BÃ©zier in the format: {{cd|{ "cubic_bezier": [ x1, y1, x2, y2 ] }}}
*** {{cd|x1}}: float between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, x-coordinate of the first control point.
*** {{cd|y1}}: float, y-coordinate of the first control point.
*** {{cd|x2}}: float between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, x-coordinate of the second control point.
*** {{cd|y2}}: float, y-coordinate of the second control point.

* Modifiers
** Added {{cd|blend_to_gray}} RGB/ARGB modifier &ndash; modifies a color by taking its grayscale form, applying a brightness modifier, and mixing with this using some factor.
*** Where {{cd|gray {{=}} brightness * (0.3 * red + 0.59 * green + 0.11 * blue), result {{=}} lerp(factor, subject, [gray, gray, gray])}}
**** Argument format: object with fields
**** {{cd|brightness}}: float between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, a multiplier to apply to the grayscale value.
**** {{cd|factor}}: float between {{cd|0}} and {{cd|1}}, the factor to mix with.

== Changes ==
=== Blocks ===
'''[[Decorated Pot]]s'''
* Now have the [[Particles (Java Edition)|particle]] texture of [[terracotta]] upon [[breaking]].{{source code ref|Before: <code>"particle": "entity/decorated_pot/decorated_pot_side"</code><br><br>After: <code>"particle": "minecraft:block/terracotta"</code>}}

=== Items ===

'''[[Elytra]]'''

'''[[Leather horse armor]]'''

'''[[Spawn Egg]]s'''

=== Mobs ===
'''[[Bat]]s'''
* No longer spawn more frequently and in higher light levels between October 20 and November 3.

'''[[Horse]]s''', '''[[mule]]s''', '''[[donkey]]s''', '''[[zombie horse]]s''' and '''[[camel]]s'''
* No longer sink in water while ridden by a player.
* Will not panic if controlled by mobs.
* Tamed horses no longer run into [[cactus]] or [[sweet berry bush]]es.

'''[[Llama]]s''' and '''[[trader llama]]s'''
* Will not panic if controlled by mobs.

'''[[Parrot]]s'''
* Now can mimic the sounds of [[zombie nautilus]], [[zombie horse]], [[camel husk]] and [[parched]].

'''[[Piglin]]'''
* Piglins can now spawn holding [[golden spear]]s and use its Jab attack.
* Piglins now consider golden spears and [[golden nautilus armor]] as items they like.

'''[[Zombie]] and [[husk]]'''  
* Zombies and husks can now spawn holding [[iron spear]]s and use its Charge attack.

[[File:Zombie Horse JE6.png|width=51x51]] '''[[Zombie horse]]'''
* Texture changed from [[File:Zombie Horse JE5 BE2.png|width=50x50]] to have a darker texture.
* Now spawns naturally, in [[plains]] and [[savanna]] biomes.
** Spawns in darkness, and burns in sunlight, like other [[undead]] mobs.
** Counts towards the hostile mob cap and spawns with other hostile mobs in the [[Mob spawning|spawning cycle]].
** Spawns being [[riding|ridden]] by a [[zombie]] holding an iron spear, forming a [[zombie horseman]].
* Has {{hp|25}} health.
** Can be healed and tempted using [[red mushroom]]s.
* Drops 2-3 [[rotten flesh]] when killed (instead of 0-2), with an extra 0-1 for each level of [[Looting]].
** The boost from Looting is the same as it was before the update.
** Any zombie riding it now has a chance of dropping a [[red mushroom]] on death.{{info needed|Does the zombie still drop the mushroom if the horse dies first, or does it work like a chicken jockey? Probably works like a chicken jockey.}}
* An unridden zombie horse does not display any hostile behavior towards players.
** If it is ridden by a zombie, the zombie will control its [[Mob AI|pathfinding]] and therefore make it hostile.
* Untamed zombie horses despawn like other hostile mobs.
** Tamed zombie horses are persistent and do not despawn.
* Can be tamed in the same fashion as a regular [[horse]], and can then be mounted and controlled by a player.
* Can be equipped with a [[saddle]] and [[horse armor]].
** Horse armor protects it from sunlight damage.
* Has variable movement speed and jump strength, determined when it spawns.

'''[[Zombie villager]]'''
* Zombie villagers can now hold Spears and use its Charge attack.
** This change was not mentioned in the changelog.

'''[[Zombified piglin]]'''
* Zombified piglins can now spawn holding golden spears and use its Charge attack.
* Zombified piglins spawned from lightning striking a [[pig]] also have a chance to hold a [[golden spear]].

=== World generation ===
'''[[Bastion remnant]]'''
* Bastion remnant chests can now contain diamond spears.

'''[[Buried treasure]]'''
* Buried treasure chests can now contain iron spears.
* Buried treasure chests can now contain copper, iron, golden and diamond nautilus armor.

'''[[End city]]'''
* End city chests can now contain diamond spears.

'''[[Ocean ruins]]'''
* Ocean ruin chests can now contain stone spears.
* Ocean ruin chests can now contain copper, iron, golden and diamond nautilus armor.

'''[[Shipwreck]]'''
* Shipwreck chests can now contain copper, iron, golden and diamond nautilus armor.

'''[[Village]]'''
* Weaponsmith chests can now contain copper and iron spears.

=== Command format ===
'''General'''
* Resource suggestions now show results in any namespace instead of just within <code>minecraft</code>.

'''{{cmd|execute}}'''
* Added new syntax {{cmd|execute (if&vert;unless) stopwatch <id> <range>}}
* Allows to compare the elapsed time of a given stopwatch with a floating point value range.
** The stopwatch value is measured in seconds and has an accuracy of at most a millisecond.
*** Example: {{cmd|execute if stopwatch foo:bar ..10 run say Stopwatch foo:bar has not reached 10 seconds yet}}.

'''{{cmd|worldborder}}'''
* The {{cd|time}} argument is now given in ticks instead of seconds.
* The {{cd|time}} argument for setting the size can now also specify seconds or in-game days using an {{cd|s}} or {{cd|d}} suffix.
* The {{cd|time}} argument for setting the warning distance now specifies ticks by default but can also specify seconds or in-game days using an {{cd|s}} or {{cd|d}} suffix.

=== Gameplay ===
'''[[Advancements]]'''
* Updated "[[How Did We Get Here?]]" to require the Breath of the Nautilus effect.
* Updated "[[Best Friends Forever]]" to include the nautilus, zombie nautilus, and zombie horse.
* Updated "[[The Parrots and the Bats]]" to include the nautilus.
* Updated "[[Two by Two]]" to require the nautilus.
* Updated "[[Monster Hunter]]" to include, and "[[Monsters Hunted]]" to require the camel husk, parched, zombie horse, and zombie nautilus.
* Updated "[[A Throwaway Joke]]", "[[Take Aim]]" and "[[It Spreads]]" to include the camel husk, parched, nautilus, and zombie nautilus.
* Updated "[[Oh Shiny]]" to include the [[golden spear]] and [[golden nautilus armor]].

'''[[Cloud]]s'''
* Cloud movement and position is now tied to the world time, hence the same for all players on a server.

'''[[Sky]]'''
* The color of the sky during sunrises and sunsets is now affected by rain and thunder.

'''[[World border]]'''
* World border interpolation is now dependent on game ticks instead of real time.
** This means the world border will no longer move when the game is paused.
** It will also respect any changes made by the {{cmd|tick}} command.

=== General ===
'''General'''
* Added support for KQueue on OSX to improve network connection performance.

'''[[Advancement trigger]]'''
* Added new {{cd|spear_mobs}} trigger with fields:
** {{cd|player}}: optional entity predicate, the player using the kinetic weapon.
** {{cd|count}}: optional integer, the number of mobs hit in a single use of the kinetic weapon.

'''[[Biome]]s'''
* Underwater biome fog color and fog distance is now blended based on the player's position between biomes, similarly to regular biome fog and sky colors.
* Added new attributes field for biomes to specify Environment Attributes.
** Note: certain attributes, such as gameplay/fast_lava are not evaluated positionally and thus cannot be set on a Biome.
* Many subfields under effects have been migrated to Environment Attributes:
** Note: the form of these attributes may not be identical to the original fields.
** {{cd|fog_color}} -> {{cd|minecraft:visual/fog_color}}
** {{cd|water_fog_color}} -> {{cd|minecraft:visual/water_fog_color}}
** {{cd|sky_color}} -> {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_color}}
** {{cd|particle}} -> {{cd|minecraft:visual/ambient_particles}}
** {{cd|ambient_sound}}, {{cd|mood_sound}}, {{cd|additions_sound}} -> {{cd|minecraft:audio/ambient_sounds}}
** {{cd|music}} -> {{cd|minecraft:audio/background_music}}
** {{cd|music_volume}} -> {{cd|minecraft:audio/music_volume}}
* The following color fields in the {{cd|effects}} definition now support colors as a string in the form "#rrggbb", or a float array in the form {{cd|[red, green, blue]}}
** {{cd|water_color}}
** {{cd|foliage_color}}
** {{cd|dry_foliage_color}}
** {{cd|grass_color}}
** {{cd|grass_color_modifier}}

'''[[Block model]]s'''
* Block model elements can now be rotated around multiple axes.
** Model is first rotated around X, then Y, then Z
** New fields:
*** {{cd|x}} &ndash; rotation around axis X in degrees, float, defaults to {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|y}} &ndash; rotation around axis Y in degrees, float, defaults to {{cd|0.0}}
*** {{cd|z}} &ndash; rotation around axis Z in degrees, float, defaults to {{cd|0.0}}
** Existing fields {{cd|axis}} and {{cd|angle}} can still be used.
*** If both field sets are present, older notation takes presence.
* Existing restriction for angle value limiting them to {{cd|[-45, 45]}} has been removed.
** Note: Names of faces are not influenced by rotation. Features that depend on them, like culling, will always use original directions.

'''[[Blockstates definition]]'''
* Variants in blockstates definition files (defined in <samp>assets/minecraft/blockstates/</samp>) can now be also rotated around Z axis.
** New optional field {{cd|z}} has the same format as existing {{cd|x}} and {{cd|y}} fields: an integer with allowed values of {{cd|0}} (default), {{cd|90}}, {{cd|180}} and {{cd|270}}.
** Rotation around Z axis is applied after X and Y.

'''[[Chunks]]'''
* Now fade in instead of appearing out of nowhere, with the fade-in time adjustable through Video Settings.

'''[[Controls]]'''
* Several uses of the {{key|cmd}} key on Mac have been rebound to {{key|Ctrl}}:
** The input modifier to drop all items.
** The input modifier to include all the data when picking a block.
** The input modifier to change GUI scale in the Video Settings screen.
** Stopping the recipe book from cycling through variations of items.

'''[[Damage type]]s'''
* Added a new <code>minecraft:spear</code> damage type.

'''[[Data pack]]'''
* The [[pack format]] version is now {{cd|94.1}}.

'''Debug renderer'''
* More debug renderers are now available through the Debug Settings screen.
* Some existing renderers were improved.
* The performance of debug renderers has been significantly improved.

'''[[Dimension type]]s'''
* Added new attributes field for dimensions to specify Environment Attributes.
* Many fields have been migrated to Environment Attributes:
** Note: the form of these attributes may not be identical to the original fields.
** {{cd|ultrawarm}} -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/water_evaporates}}, {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/fast_lava}}, {{cd|visual/default_dripstone_particle}}
** {{cd|bed_works}} -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/bed_rule}}
** {{cd|respawn_anchor_works}} -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/respawn_anchor_works}}
** {{cd|cloud_height}} -> {{cd|minecraft:visual/cloud_height}}
** {{cd|piglin_safe}} -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/piglins_zombify}}
** {{cd|has_raids}} -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/can_start_raid}}
** {{cd|natural}} (note: not removed) -> {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/nether_portal_spawns_piglin}}
* Added a new optional {{cd|timelines}} field that specifies which Timelines are active in this dimension.
** Format: a Timeline ID, a list of Timeline IDs, or a Timeline Tag.
* The {{cd|natural}} field has been fully replaced by the {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/eyeblossom_open}} and {{cd|minecraft:gameplay/creaking_active}} environment attributes.
* The {{cd|effects}} field has been removed and replaced with the following new fields:
** {{cd|skybox}} &ndash; the skybox rendering type to use, one of:
*** {{cd|none}} (was {{cd|minecraft:nether}} effect ID)
*** {{cd|overworld}} (was {{cd|minecraft:overworld}} effect ID)
**** Following environment attributes are applied only when the {{cd|skybox}} is {{cd|overworld}}:
***** {{cd|minecraft:visual/sky_color}}, {{cd|minecraft:visual/sun_angle}},{{cd|minecraft:visual/sunrise_sunset_color}}, {{cd|minecraft:visual/moon_phase}}, {{cd|minecraft:visual/moon_angle}}, {{cd|minecraft:visual/star_angle}}, {{cd|minecraft:visual/star_brightness}}
*** {{cd|end}} (was {{cd|minecraft:end}} effect ID)
*** Default: {{cd|overworld}}
** {{cd|cardinal_light}} &ndash; the direction of cardinal lighting that affects blocks, one of:
*** {{cd|default}} (was {{cd|minecraft:overworld}} and {{cd|minecraft:end}} effect ID).
*** {{cd|nether}} (was {{cd|minecraft:nether}} effect ID).
*** Default: {{cd|default}}
* The {{cd|fixed_time}} field has been replaced by a {{cd|has_fixed_time}} boolean (default: {{cd|false}})
** Time-based effects such as the angle of the sun are now specified instead by environment attributes.
** However, the remainder of behaviors formerly affected by {{cd|fixed_time}} being present will now instead use the {{cd|has_fixed_time}} boolean.

'''[[Enchantment definition]]'''
* Added {{cd|exponent}}
** Raises the base to the specified power level.
*** {{cd|base}} &ndash; Level-Based Value indicating the base of the exponent.
*** {{cd|power}} &ndash; Level-Based Value indicating the power of the exponent.

* Enchantment Effect Components
** {{cd|minecraft:post_piercing_attack}}: Effects applying after a piercing attack with an item.

* Enchantment Entity Effects
** {{cd|minecraft:apply_exhaustion}}: applies exhaustion to the targeted entity.
*** {{cd|amount}} &ndash; Level-Based Value indicating the amount of exhaustion to apply.
*** Effective only on players.
** {{cd|minecraft:apply_impulse}}: applies an impulse to the targeted entity.
*** {{cd|direction}} &ndash; The first step of determining the impulse is applying this vector as local coordinates (the same used by {{cmd|tp @s ^ ^ ^}}) onto the entity look vector.
*** {{cd|coordinate_scale}} &ndash; The second step is scaling the resulting vector by this vector on each axis in world space, X, Y and Z.
*** {{cd|magnitude}} &ndash; The third step is scaling the resulting vector by this Level-Based Value.
** {{cd|minecraft:play_sound}}: can now support a list of sound event identifiers, one for each level of enchantment. If a level is higher than the number of sounds, the last sound in the list is used.

'''[[Entity data]]'''
* The {{cd|AngryAt}} field has been renamed to {{cd|angry_at}}.
* The {{cd|AngerTime}} field has been removed.
* An {{cd|anger_end_time}} (long) field has been added, containing the time anger ends in game ticks.

'''[[Fog]]'''

*** {{cd|spawnerBlocksEnabled}} -> {{cd|minecraft:spawner_blocks_work}}
* Limits
** Some game rules that previously did not have a limited value range now do:
*** {{cd|minecraft:max_block_modifications}}: Minimum {{cd|1}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:max_command_forks}}: Minimum {{cd|1}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:max_command_sequence_length}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:max_entity_cramming}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:max_snow_accumulation_height}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}, maximum: {{cd|8}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:players_nether_portal_creative_delay}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:players_nether_portal_default_delay}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:players_sleeping_percentage}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:random_tick_speed}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:respawn_radius}}: Minimum {{cd|0}}

'''[[Game Tests]]'''
* In the {{cd|game_rules}} test environment the keys {{cd|bool_rule}} and {{cd|int_rule}} have been replaced with a single key rules. 
** It is a map from game rules resource locations to the game rules value. The value type is either integer or boolean depending on the game rule.

'''[[Graphics]]'''
* The "See-Through Leaves" video setting is now turned off on the "Fast" graphics preset.
* Disabling the "See-Through Leaves" video setting now improves performance more than before because leaves occluded faces are now culled.

'''[[Data component format|Item components]]'''
* {{cd|minecraft:consumable}}
** The animation field has been updated:
*** Renamed {{cd|spear}} to {{cd|trident}}
*** Added new {{cd|spear}} animation.

* {{cd|minecraft:intangible}}
** Items with this component now show information about it in their tooltip.

* Added food properties to the following fish bucket items:
** {{cd|minecraft:cod_bucket}}
** {{cd|minecraft:salmon_bucket}}
** {{cd|minecraft:pufferfish_bucket}}
** {{cd|minecraft:tropical_fish_bucket}}

'''[[Item model]]s'''
* Added new option for all item models: 
** {{cd|swap_animation_scale}}
*** Defaults to {{cd|1.0}}
*** Indicates how fast the item moves up and down when swapping items in hotbar.
*** Large speeds can allow items that take more of the screen space to fully duck before swapped into the next item.
* Added new item model:
** {{cd|spear_in_hand}} &ndash; model for the [[spear]] when in hand.

'''[[Key binds]]'''
* Added a Debug category category in the key binds screen.
* Keys used to access debug features can now be rebound.
* The debug modifier key can be bound separately from the debug overlay key.
* The key to toggle GUI can now be rebound.
* The key to toggle spectator shader effects, such as when spectating an [[enderman]], can now be rebound.

'''[[Loot functions]]'''
* {{cd|minecraft:filtered}}
** The field {{cd|modifier}} has been replaced with two fields:
*** {{cd|on_pass}} &ndash; function or a list of functions to run when {{cd|item_filter}} predicate passes.
*** {{cd|on_fail}} &ndash; function or a list of functions to run when {{cd|item_filter}} predicate fails.

'''[[Loot table]]s'''
* Added new {{cd|minecraft:slots}} loot pool entry.
** Provides the items contained within the selected slots to the loot table.
** Format:
*** {{cd|slot_source}}: a slot source describing where the items are located.
** Supports all standard loot pool entry fields.

'''[[Minecraft Server Management Protocol]]'''
* The version is now 2.0.0.
* Added a new notification server/activity.
** Indicates that a network connection to the server has been initiated.
** Rate limited to 1 notification per 30 seconds.
* Enable authentication from web browsers.
** Authenticate by passing the token in <code>Sec-WebSocket-Protocol</code> header when opening the WebSocket connection.
*** Example: <code>Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: minecraft-v1, <token></code>
** Requests authenticating this way are subject to Origin header checks. This requires configuration of allowed origins on the server side using <code>management-server-allowed-origins</code>. The default value is empty, meaning <code>Sec-Websocket-Protocol</code> authentication is effectively disabled.
* In the {{cd|typed_game_rule}} and {{cd|untyped_game_rule}} schemas, the type of the value field has been changed from string to take either a boolean or an integer.
** It now uses the game rule resource location as the key.

'''[[Mob variant definitions]]'''
* Zombie Nautilus Variants
** Zombie Nautilus variants can be data-driven by adding entries to <samp>data/<namespace>/zombie_nautilus_variant/<id>.json</samp>
*** This feature is experimental.
*** Fields in file:
**** {{cd|model}} &ndash; one of: normal, warm
**** {{cd|asset_id}} &ndash; namespaced id for this variant asset, resolves to <samp>assets/<namespace>/textures/<path>.png</samp>
**** {{cd|spawn_conditions}} &ndash; a uniform variant selection rule.
** Spawn conditions
*** {{cd|minecraft:biome}}
**** Checks if entity is spawning in specific biomes.
**** Fields:
***** {{cd|biomes}} &ndash; single entry, list or a tag describing biomes.
*** {{cd|minecraft:moon_brightness}}
**** Checks if current moon brightness is within certain range.
**** Fields:
***** range &ndash; floating point range (a single number or an object like {{cd|{"min": 1, "max": 2})}}
*** {{cd|minecraft:structures}}
**** Checks if entity is spawning in specific structures.
**** Fields:
***** {{cd|structures}} &ndash; single entry, list or a tag describing structures.

'''[[Options]]'''
* Renamed the "Show Music Toast" option to "Music Toast".
** Added a third state to the "Music Toast" option, allowing it to only be shown in the pause menu.

'''[[Panorama]]'''
* Updated the panorama to resemble [[Mounts of Mayhem]].

'''[[Predicate]]s'''
* Component Predicates
** Component predicates (predicates field in block, item and entity predicates) now include predicates for checking existence of every component type.
** Those predicates are written as <code>{<component_type>: {}}</code>.
** Such predicate check passes as long as component is present, no matter the actual value.
** Existing predicates for specific components remain unchanged.
** Example:
*** <code>{predicates:{written_book_content:{author:"foo"}}</code> &ndash; existing format for matching books.
*** <code>{predicates:{written_book_content:{}}</code> &ndash; special case of above that accepted any value, as long as component existed.
*** <code>{predicates:{instrument:{}}</code> &ndash; checks if component <code>minecraft:instrument</code> exists (was not allowed before).

* Entity Predicates
** The {{cd|flags}} predicate now supports new values:
*** {{cd|is_in_water}}: when an entity is touching [[water]] or a [[bubble column]].
*** {{cd|is_fall_flying}}: when an entity is gliding with an [[elytra]].

* Item Predicates
** Item predicate in command form (<code><item>[predicate~{...},component={...}]</code>) has been extended to accept empty predicates for any component type.
** Similarly to component predicates in data, those empty entries only check for component existence.
** Existing shorter syntax for checking component existence remains unchanged.
*** That means {{cd|*[instrument]}} and {{cd|*[instrument~{}]}} are equivalent.

'''[[Resource pack]]'''
* The version is now {{cd|75.0}}.
* <samp>block.vsh/fsh</samp> copies <samp>terrain.vsh/fsh</samp> and handles ad-hoc blocks (e.g. held by entities).
* Added {{cd|ChunkSection}} uniform, used by <samp>terrain.vsh</samp> (which replaces {{cd|DynamicTransforms}}).
* New shaders have been introduced to perform GPU based sprite animations.
* {{cd|Globals}} uniform now has camera coordinates.
* <samp>terrain</samp> core shader now samples the blocks atlas texture linearly instead of with nearest neighbour
* Block model and state format has been expanded to allow more rotations.

'''[[Server]]'''
* Added ClientFps JFR event.
* Experience packets that do not change the player's experience progress or level are no longer sent by the server.
* Client FPS is expected to be higher for most players.

'''[[Settings]]'''
* Graphics modes "Fast", "Fancy", and "Fabulous!" have been replaced with graphics presets with the same names.
* Settings on the Video Settings screen have been reordered and split into 3 sections: "Display", "Quality & Performance", and "Interface".
** The following settings that have been removed from the Video Settings screen, because were duplicating accessibility settings:
*** "View Bobbing"
*** "Glint Speed"
*** "Glint Strength"
*** "FOV Effects"
*** "Distortion Effects"
** Tweaks that were previously hidden behind the "Graphics" setting have been split out to be configurable independently:
*** "See-Through Leaves"
*** "Show Vignette"
*** "Weather Effect Radius" 
**** Configures the distance in blocks within which rain and snow are visible.
*** "Improved Transparency" 
**** Resolves some of the transparent geometry rendering issues at a significant GPU cost, previously was hidden behind "Fabulous!".
** A new "Preset" slider was added to the top of the "Quality & Performance" section.
*** Presets control most of the "Quality & Performance" settings at once, not only the ones that were previously hidden behind the "Graphics" setting.
*** Available presets are "Fast", "Fancy", "Fabulous!" and "Custom"
*** The default preset is "Fancy" for new players.
*** But for players who are upgrading to this version the preset will be set to "Custom" to preserve the current configuration.

'''[[Shaders]] & Post-process Effects'''
* Added {{cd|animate_sprite*}} core shaders, which use a new {{cd|SpriteAnimationInfo}} uniform.

'''[[Sounds]]'''
* [[Anvil]] destroy, land, place and use sounds now play at a slightly lower volume.

'''Sprite Animations'''
* Sprites (textures as part of a larger atlas) are now animated on the GPU rather than per-tick on the CPU.
* For regular frame-based animations, <samp>animate_sprite.vsh</samp> and <samp>animate_sprite_blit.fsh</samp> are used to perform the draw.
* For interpolated animations, <samp>animate_sprite.vsh</samp> and <samp>animate_sprite_interpolate.fsh</samp> are used to perform the draw.
* The UBO {{cd|SpriteAnimationInfo}} contains information on where the sprite should be drawn to, within the greater texture atlas.

'''[[Statistics]]'''
* Added {{cd|minecraft:nautilus_one_cm}} statistic (Distance By Nautilus).

'''[[Tag (Java Edition)|Tags]]'''
* Biome Tags
** Removed {{cd|d=and|#snow_golem_melts|#increased_fire_burnout}} &ndash; replaced by {{cd|d=and|gameplay/snow_golem_melts|gameplay/increased_fire_burnout}} Environment Attributes.
** Removed {{cd|#plays_underwater_music}} &ndash; replaced by {{cd|only_underwater}} field in the {{cd|audio/background_music}} Environment Attribute.
** Removed {{cd|#has_closer_water_fog}} &ndash; replaced by {{cd|visual/water_fog_radius}} Environment Attribute.
** Removed {{cd|#without_patrol_spawns}} &ndash; replaced by {{cd|gameplay/can_pillager_patrol_spawn}} Environment Attribute.
* Damage Tags
** Added {{cd|spear}} to {{cd|d=and|#is_player_attack|#no_knockback}} tags.
* Enchantment Tags
** Added {{cd|lunge}} to {{cd|d=and|#non_treasure|tooltip_order}} tags.
* Entity Tags
** Added {{cd|d=and|camel_husk|nautilus|zombie_nautilus}} to {{cd|#can_equip_saddle}} tags.
** Added {{cd|nautilus}} to {{cd|#can_breathe_under_water}} tag.
** Added {{cd|d=and|nautilus|zombie_nautilus}} to {{cd|d=and|#aquatic|#cannot_be_pushed_onto_boats|#not_scary_for_pufferfish}} tags.
** Added {{cd|zombie_horse}} to {{cd|#can_wear_horse_armor}} tag.
** Added {{cd|parched}} to {{cd|#skeletons}} tag.
** Added {{cd|camel_husk|zombie_nautilus}} to {{cd|#zombies}} tag.
* Item Tags
** Added {{cd|d=and|golden_nautilus_armor|golden_spear}} to {{cd|#piglin_loved}} tag.
** Added {{cd|golden_spear}} to {{cd|#piglin_preferred_weapons}} tag.
** Added {{cd|#spears}} to {{cd|#enchantable/durability}} tag.
** Renamed tag {{cd|#enchantable/sword}} to {{cd|#enchantable/sweeping}}.
** Renamed {{cd|#enchantable/sword}} to {{cd|#enchantable/melee_weapon}} from {{cd|#enchantable/fire_aspect}} tag.
** Renamed {{cd|#swords}} to {{cd|#enchantable/melee_weapon}} from {{cd|#enchantable/sharp_weapon}} tag.

'''[[Texture atlas]]es'''
* Item textures were split out of the blocks atlas into a separate new items atlas that does not have mipmaps.
** All textures used in an item model have to come from the same (items or blocks) atlas.
** All textures used in a block model have to come from the blocks atlas.
** Commands that were referencing the blocks atlas for item textures now need to reference the items atlas instead.
* To prepare for future work, the game will now print a warning if any defined sprites in any atlases share a name.

* <samp>[[celestials.png-atlas]]</samp>
** A new celestials atlas has been introduced, including sprites for objects rendered in the sky such as the Sun and Moon.
** Includes sprites from <samp><namespace>:textures/environment/celestial/<path>.png</samp>
** The following textures have been moved or split:
*** <samp>textures/environment/sun.png</samp> -> <samp>sun</samp>
*** <samp>textures/environment/end_flash.png</samp> -> <samp>end_flash</samp>
*** <samp>textures/environment/moon_phases</samp> -> <samp>moon/full_moon</samp>, <samp>moon/waning_gibbous</samp>, <samp>moon/third_quarter</samp>, <samp>moon/waning_crescent</samp>, <samp>moon/new_moon</samp>, <samp>moon/waxing_crescent</samp>, <samp>moon/first_quarter</samp>, <samp>moon/waxing_gibbous</samp>

'''[[Textures]]'''
* All blocks in the world now have mipmaps applied if enabled in video settings.
** Blocks that did not have mipmaps before, such as different vines, rails, foliage (apart from leaves) and more should look better from higher distances.
* Only mipmaps of level 0 and 1 are now animated for block animated textures.
* [[Glass]] and [[glass panes]] now support translucent textures.
* All mipmap levels are once again animated for block animated textures.
* Beacon and redstone dust now support translucent textures.
* Textures used for still water and lava are now hardcoded to {{cd|minecraft:block/water_still}} and {{cd|minecraft:block/lava_still}}.
* Beacons no longer support translucent textures.
* Added <samp>gui/container/nautilus</samp> used for the Nautilus inventory UI.

* {{cd|texture}} section of {{cd|*.mcmeta}} files has a new field {{cd|mipmap_strategy}} with the following supported values:
** {{cd|mean}} averages both color and alpha between groups of four pixels for the current mipmap level to generate the next mipmap level pixel. This was and stays the default strategy for most solid or translucent full block textures.
** {{cd|dark_cutout}} is similar to {{cd|mean}}, but blends colors in a way that makes the pixels bordering cutout pixels darker. This was and stays the strategy for leaves and mangrove roots. It simulates dark interior of the blocks.
** {{cd|cutout}} is a new strategy that always generates a mipmap based on the original texture instead of the previous mipmap. Used for most cutout blocks that became mipmapped in this version.
** {{cd|strict_cutout}} is a modification of {{cd|cutout}} that uses stricter alpha cutoff value leading to the textures using this value disappearing at higher mipmap levels. Is used for flowers and similar blocks to avoid artifacts.
** {{cd|auto}} is the default value and will make the game to pick {{cd|mean}} for textures that do not contain fully transparent pixels and {{cd|cutout}} for those that do.

* {{cd|texture}} section of {{cd|*.mcmeta}} files has a new {{cd|alpha_cutoff_bias}} field that controls alpha bias for cutout textures.
** There is no limit for this value technically, it can be negative as well, but it does not make sense to set this higher than {{cd|1.0}} or lower than {{cd|-1.0}} since the texture will become either fully opaque or fully transparent.
** Default value for this field is {{cd|0.0}}, and it can be increased for textures that can become too transparent/thin at distance, or decreased if it's too "opaque".
** Only used for lower mips of cutout textures, does not change the alpha of first mip level, and has no effect on other textures.

'''[[UI]]'''
* Menu sliders will now "stick" to the closest available value when releasing them after dragging with a mouse.
* When using keyboard to change slider values, arrow keys will now move the slider to the next available value, not by one pixel as before.
* The inF3 button in the Debug Option screen has been renamed to inOverlay.
* "Interface" option inside the Video Settings screen has been renamed to "Preferences".
* The Single Biome Customization screen now has a search box.
* The language selection screen now has a search box to filter languages.

'''UI Sprites'''
* Added new UI sprites:
** <samp>container/slot/nautilus_armor</samp>
** <samp>container/slot/nautilus_armor_inventory</samp>
*** Nautilus icon used in Nautilus inventory UI.
** <samp>container/slot/spear</samp>
*** [[Spear]] icon used in the [[smithing table]] screen.
* Added new nine-sliced sprites:
** <samp>container/inventory/effect_background</samp>
** <samp>container/inventory/effect_background_ambient</samp>
* Removed the following sprites:
** <samp>container/inventory/effect_background_large</samp>
** <samp>container/inventory/effect_background_small</samp>

== Trivia ==
* 1.21.11 has the highest minor version number of any {{JE}} release version, beating the previous records of [[Java Edition 1.7.10|1.7.10]] and [[Java Edition 1.21.10|1.21.10]].
** This is also the third {{JE}} public release with minor version at "11" overall, following [[Java Edition Classic 0.0.11a|Classic 0.0.11a]] in 2009 and [[Alpha v1.0.11]] in 2010.
* This is the first version of {{MC}} to have its code unobfuscated.
* This version was released exactly ten years after [[Java Edition 1.8.9|1.8.9]] and [[Java Edition 15w50a|15w50a]].
* The unobfuscated release candidates for this version share the record for the longest version string of all {{JE}} versions, at 40 characters.
